Evidence_Assessment: Inconsistencies between applicant's allegations and country documentation
Burden_of_Proof: On the applicant to establish credibility and risk of persecution
Credibility_Factor: Inconsistencies in testimony versus objective evidence
Legal_Rule: RAD must respect RPD's credibility findings unless demonstrable error exists
Procedural_Issue: Whether RAD conducted adequate analysis within its jurisdiction
Grounds_for_Claim: Fear of persecution due to husband's political activities
Outcome_on_Merits: Claim dismissed for lack of credible evidence
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: RAD conducted thorough and fair review
Legal_Framework: Canadian refugee determination system, IRPA, Charter of Rights and Freedoms
Applicant_Challenge: RAD failed to properly assess credibility findings of RPD
Legal_Rule_Source: Statute, case law on standard of review
Defendant_Response: Not applicable – administrative decision under review
Remedy_Requested: Leave for judicial review, quashing of RAD decision
Remedy_Sought: Overturning of RAD's negative credibility assessment
Authority: Refugee Protection Division, Refugee Appeal Division, Federal Court
Legal_Provision_Cited: IRPA s. 101(1)(a), principles of reasonableness review from Dunsmuir v. New Brunswick
Grounds_for_Inadmissibility_or_Allegatio: Lack of credible basis for fear of persecution
Applicable_Process: Refugee appeal and judicial review process
Outcome_of_Review: No error found in RAD's assessment
Jurisdiction: Federal jurisdiction – immigration and refugee law
Governing_Rule: Principles of administrative law, reasonableness standard
